questions.question: Given that the coefficients of static friction and kinetic friction between steel and concrete are 0.35 and 0.20 respectively, calculate the force of kinetic friction acting on a 8 kg steel block sliding across a horizontal concrete floor. Take $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.

A concrete brick is pushed across a flat workshop floor. The brick has a mass of 12.5 kg. Calculate the magnitude of the kinetic friction force acting on the brick, given that the coefficient of static friction ($\mu_s$) is 0.65 and the coefficient of kinetic friction ($\mu_k$) is 0.48. (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)

A metal box with a mass of 6.0 kg sits at rest on a rough horizontal surface. The coefficient of static friction ($\mu_s$) between the box and the surface is 0.3. If a horizontal pull of 15 N is applied to the box, calculate the resulting acceleration of the box. (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: $f_{s,max} = \mu_s mg = 0.3 \times 60 = 18\text{ N}$. Applied force 15 N < 18 N, so box doesn't move, $a = 0$.

questions.question: Two crates, Crate X and Crate Y, are stacked on top of each other on a frictionless floor. Crate X (mass 2 kg) sits on top of Crate Y (mass 8 kg). A horizontal force of 40 N is applied to the bottom crate (Y), causing the entire system to accelerate together across a distance of 10 m. If the crates do not slip against each other, what is the magnitude of the frictional force exerted by Crate Y on Crate X? (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: $a = F/m_{total} = 40/10 = 4\text{ m/s}^2$. For crate X: $f = m_X a = 2 \times 4 = 8\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A 15 kg wooden crate is being pulled across a horizontal floor by a rope. The rope exerts a force of 60 N at an angle of 30° above the horizontal. The coefficient of kinetic friction ($\mu_k$) between the crate and the floor is 0.25. Calculate the magnitude of the Normal Force acting on the crate. (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)

A 15 kg wooden crate is being pulled across a horizontal floor by a rope. The rope exerts a force of 60 N at an angle of 30° above the horizontal. The coefficient of kinetic friction ($\mu_k$) between the crate and the floor is 0.25. Calculate the magnitude of the Kinetic Friction force opposing the motion. (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)

A 15 kg wooden crate is being pulled across a horizontal floor by a rope. The rope exerts a force of 60 N at an angle of 30° above the horizontal. The coefficient of kinetic friction ($\mu_k$) between the crate and the floor is 0.25. Calculate the magnitude of the acceleration of the crate. (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)
A 20 kg box is pushed across a floor. If it experiences a frictional force of 70 N and accelerates at 3 m/s², calculate the magnitude of the applied force.
questions.explanation: $F_{net} = ma = 20 \times 3 = 60\text{ N}$. $F_{net} = F_{app} - f_k$ ⇒ $60 = F_{app} - 70$ ⇒ $F_{app} = 130\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A 60 kg heavy-duty crate sits stationary on a gritty warehouse floor. A horizontal winch pulls the crate with a constant force $T$, which is exactly the minimum amount required to break the crate free and start it moving. Once the crate begins to slide, the winch continues to pull with that same constant force $T$. If the coefficient of static friction ($\mu_s$) is 0.6, the coefficient of kinetic friction ($\mu_k$) is 0.4, and $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$, calculate the acceleration of the crate once it is in motion.

A 2.5 kg textbook is held stationary against a vertical classroom wall by pressing a hand horizontally against it with a force $P$. The coefficient of static friction ($\mu_s$) between the book and the wall is 0.25. Calculate the minimum horizontal force $P$ required to prevent the textbook from sliding down the wall. (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)
